required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Sleep To Reduce Incident Depression Effectively
clinical_study.official_title: Sleep To Reduce Incident Depression Effectively

brief_summary.textblock: This project will assess the effectiveness of a stepped-care model (i.e. digital Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (dCBT-I) followed by face-to-face CBT-I) in improving severity of insomnia and sleep outcomes in an insomnia cohort, including those at higher risk of depression. This project will also investigate the effectiveness of this stepped-care model in prevention of depression and any potential mediation by rumination as a modifiable behavior.

detailed_description.textblock:
This project will assess the acute and long-term effectiveness of dCBT-I on Research Domain Criteria (RDoC) sleep parameters: Insomnia Severity Index (ISI), sleep onset latency, and wake after sleep onset in an insomnia cohort including those at elevated risk for depression (e.g. high sleep reactivity, low SES, minority). This will be tested by administering internet-based dCBT-I to people with insomnia and adding face-to-face CBT-I in non-remitters (ISI > 10), as well aS comparing the RDoC sleep outcomes to an attention control group post-treatment and at 1 year follow-up. This study will also determine the acute and long-term effectiveness of face-to-face CBT-I for insomnia in non-responders to dCBT-I on RDoC sleep outcomes relative to a comparison group post-treatment and at 1-year follow-up.
This study will also determine the effects of dCBT-I and CBT-I using a stepped-care model for prevention of incident depression and depression relapse. The 1-year rate of depression of both dCBT-I and CBT-I will be compared to a control group.
This study will also evaluate changes in nocturnal rumination as a modifiable behavior (post-treatment) that mediates the effect of insomnia treatment on subsequent depression risk. This will also determine the moderating effects of important depression risk factors (e.g. race, SES) on the change in sleep and depression outcomes.

primary_outcome.measure: Prevention of Incident Depression and Depression Relapse 2-years Post Treatment
primary_outcome.description: Rate of Incidence of depression determined by score on the Quick Inventory of Depressive Symptomatology (QIDS; if total score > 12, possible range 0-27, with higher scores meaning greater severity) and confirmed by Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-5 (SCIDS)

secondary_outcome.measure: Mediation of Prevention of Depression by Ruminating Behavior - Post Treatment
secondary_outcome.description: Rumination as determined by Thought Control Questionnaire for Insomnia - Revised (TCQI-R; total score range 35-151, with higher scores meaning more rumination)

secondary_outcome.measure: Mediation of Prevention of Depression by Ruminating Behavior - 1 year Post Treatment
secondary_outcome.description: Rumination as determined by Thought Control Questionnaire for Insomnia - Revised (TCQI-R; total score range 35-151, with higher scores meaning more rumination)

secondary_outcome.measure: Mediation of Prevention of Depression by Ruminating Behavior - 2 years Post Treatment
secondary_outcome.description: Rumination as determined by Thought Control Questionnaire for Insomnia - Revised (TCQI-R; total score range 35-151, with higher scores meaning more rumination)

secondary_outcome.measure: Moderating Effect of Depression Risk-Factors in Effectiveness of Treatment - Post Treatment
secondary_outcome.description: Race, SES, Sleep Reactivity (Ford Insomnia Response to Stress Test, FIRST; total score range 0-27, with higher scores meaning greater reactivity) as moderating effect upon Research Domain Criteria (RDoC) outcomes (Sleep Onset Latency, Wake After Sleep Onset)

secondary_outcome.measure: Moderating Effect of Depression Risk-Factors in Effectiveness of Treatment - 1 year Post Treatment
secondary_outcome.description: Race, SES, Sleep Reactivity (Ford Insomnia Response to Stress Test, FIRST; total score range 0-27, with higher scores meaning greater reactivity) as moderating effect upon Research Domain Criteria (RDoC) outcomes (Sleep Onset Latency, Wake After Sleep Onset)

secondary_outcome.measure: Moderating Effect of Depression Risk-Factors in Effectiveness of Treatment - 2 years Post Treatment
secondary_outcome.description: Race, SES, Sleep Reactivity (Ford Insomnia Response to Stress Test, FIRST; total score range 0-27, with higher scores meaning greater reactivity) as moderating effect upon Research Domain Criteria (RDoC) outcomes (Sleep Onset Latency, Wake After Sleep Onset)

secondary_outcome.measure: Severity of Symptoms of Insomnia - Post Treatment
secondary_outcome.description: Insomnia Severity Index Score (ISI; total score range 0-28, with higher scores meaning greater severity)

secondary_outcome.measure: Severity of Symptoms of Insomnia - 1 year Post Treatment
secondary_outcome.description: Insomnia Severity Index Score (ISI; total score range 0-28, with higher scores meaning greater severity)

secondary_outcome.measure: Severity of Symptoms of Insomnia - 2 years Post Treatment
secondary_outcome.description: Insomnia Severity Index Score (ISI; total score range 0-28, with higher scores meaning greater severity)

secondary_outcome.measure: Prevention of Incident Depression and Depression Relapse Post-Treatment
secondary_outcome.description: Rate of Incidence of depression determined by score on the Quick Inventory of Depressive Symptomatology (QIDS; if total score > 12, possible range 0-27, with higher scores meaning greater severity) and confirmed by Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-5 (SCIDS)

secondary_outcome.measure: Prevention of Incident Depression and Depression Relapse 1-year Post Treatment
secondary_outcome.description: Rate of Incidence of depression determined by score on the Quick Inventory of Depressive Symptomatology (QIDS; if total score > 12; possible range 0-27, with higher scores meaning greater severity) and confirmed by Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-5 (SCIDS)

arm_group.description: This group receives sleep hygiene education, which serves as a credible control intervention to digital cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (dCBT-I). This intervention mimics the web-based patient contact inherent in dCBT-I but is inert with respect to sleep outcomes.

This group receives digital Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (dCBT-I) through the third party program, "Sleepio." Following initial treatment with dCBT-I, individuals who do not experience remission of their insomnia will begin treatment with face-to-face Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia with a trained staff member in behavioral sleep medicine.

This group receives digital Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (dCBT-I) through the third party program, "Sleepio." Following initial treatment with dCBT-I, individuals who do not experience remission of their insomnia will receive sleep hygiene education, serving as a credible control intervention for comparison to the Stepped Care Model.

This group receives digital Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (dCBT-I) through the third party program, "Sleepio." Treatment includes weekly sessions of CBT-I administered over the internet in hour-long video sessions. Daily sleep diaries are recorded online for individual tailoring of treatment.

intervention.intervention_name: digital Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia
intervention.description: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia administered online through the "Sleepio" program. Treatment utilizes sleep restriction, stimulus control, and cognitive therapy. Treatment is administered through 6 weekly, hour-long online video sessions with an animated figure called "The Prof," which delivers the treatment.

intervention.intervention_name: face-to-face Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia
intervention.description: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia administered by experienced staff trained in behavioral sleep medicine. Treatment utilizes sleep restriction, stimulus control, and cognitive therapy. Treatment is administered through 6 weekly, hour-long face-to-face sessions with an experienced staff member trained in behavioral sleep medicine.
Participants are provided with information about good sleep hygiene through 6 weekly emails. Participants practice good sleep hygiene as part of their sleep routine.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Determination of Insomnia (ISI > 14)
- Without Depression (QIDS < 11)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Age < 18
- Current use of antidepressants for depression
- Bipolar or Seizure disorders
- Known sleep disorders other than insomnia (e.g. obstructive sleep apnea, narcolepsy, restless leg syndrome).
